2. Hazard(s) identification.1: This chemical is considered hazardous by the 2012 OSHA Hazard Communication Standard (29 CFR 1910.1200)
2. Hazard(s) identification.8: Specific target organ toxicity (single exposure) Category 3
2. Hazard(s) identification.9: Target Organs - Respiratory system, Central nervous system (CNS).
2. Hazard(s) identification.10: Specific target organ toxicity - (repeated exposure) Category 2
2. Hazard(s) identification.11: Target Organs - Heart, Liver, Kidney, Blood.
2. Hazard(s) identification.13: Page 1 / 10Chloroform, stabilized with ethanol Revision Date 24-Dec-2021
2. Hazard(s) identification.26: Suspected of damaging the unborn child
2. Hazard(s) identification.27: May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure
2. Hazard(s) identification.31: Do not handle until all safety precautions have been read and understood
2. Hazard(s) identification.32: Use personal protective equipment as required
2. Hazard(s) identification.33: Wash face, hands and any exposed skin thoroughly after handling
2. Hazard(s) identification.34: Do not eat, drink or smoke when using this product
2. Hazard(s) identification.35: Use only outdoors or in a well-ventilated area
2. Hazard(s) identification.IF INHALED: Remove victim to fresh air and keep at rest in a position comfortable for breathing
2. Hazard(s) identification.IF ON SKIN: Wash with plenty of soap and water
2. Hazard(s) identification.45: Take off contaminated clothing and wash before reuse
2. Hazard(s) identification.IF IN EYES: Rinse cautiously with water for several minutes. Remove contact lenses, if present and easy to do. Continue rinsing
2. Hazard(s) identification.IF SWALLOWED: Call a POISON CENTER or doctor/physician if you feel unwell
2. Hazard(s) identification.54: Store in a well-ventilated place. Keep container tightly closed
2. Hazard(s) identification.56: Dispose of contents/container to an approved waste disposal plant

4. First-aid measures.0: General Advice Show this safety data sheet to the doctor in attendance. Immediate medical attention is
4. First-aid measures.2: Eye Contact Rinse immediately with plenty of water, also under the eyelids, for at least 15 minutes. In
4. First-aid measures.3: the case of contact with eyes, rinse immediately with plenty of water and seek medical
4. First-aid measures.5: Skin Contact Wash off immediately with plenty of water for at least 15 minutes. Immediate medical
4. First-aid measures.7: Inhalation Remove to fresh air. If not breathing, give artificial respiration. Do not use mouth-to-mouth
4. First-aid measures.8: method if victim ingested or inhaled the substance; give artificial respiration with the aid of a
4. First-aid measures.9: pocket mask equipped with a one-way valve or other proper respiratory medical device.
4. First-aid measures.11: Ingestion Do NOT induce vomiting. Call a physician or poison control center immediately.
4. First-aid measures.12: Most important symptoms and . Symptoms of overexposure are dizziness, headache, tiredness, nausea,
4. First-aid measures.effects unconsciousness, cessation of br: May cause decreases in blood pressure and

5. Fire-fighting measures.0: Suitable Extinguishing Media Substance is nonflammable; use agent most appropriate to extinguish surrounding fire.
5. Fire-fighting measures.1: Unsuitable Extinguishing Media No information available
5. Fire-fighting measures.8: Sensitivity to Mechanical ImpactNo information available
5. Fire-fighting measures.9: Sensitivity to Static Discharge No information available
5. Fire-fighting measures.10: Specific Hazards Arising from the Chemical
5. Fire-fighting measures.11: Non-combustible, substance itself does not burn but may decompose upon heating to produce corrosive and/or toxic fumes.
5. Fire-fighting measures.13: Carbon monoxide (CO). Carbon dioxide (CO2). Phosgene. Hydrogen chloride gas.
5. Fire-fighting measures.14: Protective Equipment and Precautions for Firefighters
5. Fire-fighting measures.15: As in any fire, wear self-contained breathing apparatus pressure-demand, MSHA/NIOSH (approved or equivalent) and full
5. Fire-fighting measures.16: protective gear. Thermal decomposition can lead to release of irritating gases and vapors.
5. Fire-fighting measures.21: Page 3 / 10Chloroform, stabilized with ethanol Revision Date 24-Dec-2021

6. Accidental release measures.0: Personal Precautions Ensure adequate ventilation. Use personal protective equipment as required. Keep people
6. Accidental release measures.1: away from and upwind of spill/leak. Evacuate personnel to safe areas.
6. Accidental release measures.2: Environmental Precautions Should not be released into the environment.
6. Accidental release measures.3: Methods for Containment and CleanSoak up with inert absorbent material. Keep in suitable, closed containers for disposal.

7. Handling and storage.0: Handling Wear personal protective equipment/face protection. Do not get in eyes, on skin, or on
7. Handling and storage.1: clothing. Use only under a chemical fume hood. Do not breathe mist/vapors/spray. Do not
7. Handling and storage.2: ingest. If swallowed then seek immediate medical assistance.
7. Handling and storage.3: Storage. Keep containers tightly closed in a dry, cool and well-ventilated place. Protect from direct
7. Handling and storage.4: sunlight. Store under an inert atmosphere. Protect from moisture. Incompatible Materials.
7. Handling and storage.5: Strong oxidizing agents. Alkali metals. Aluminium. Acetone.

8. Exposure controls / personal protecti.9: OSHA - Occupational Safety and Health Administration
8. Exposure controls / personal protecti.NIOSH IDLH: NIOSH - National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health
8. Exposure controls / personal protecti.11: Engineering Measures Use only under a chemical fume hood. Ensure adequate ventilation, especially in confined
8. Exposure controls / personal protecti.12: areas. Ensure that eyewash stations and safety showers are close to the workstation
8. Exposure controls / personal protecti.15: Eye/face Protection Wear appropriate protective eyeglasses or chemical safety goggles as described by
8. Exposure controls / personal protecti.16: OSHA's eye and face protection regulations in 29 CFR 1910.133 or European Standard
8. Exposure controls / personal protecti.17: EN166. Tight sealing safety goggles. Face protection shield.
8. Exposure controls / personal protecti.18: Skin and body protection Wear appropriate protective gloves and clothing to prevent skin exposure.
8. Exposure controls / personal protecti.19: Respiratory Protection Follow the OSHA respirator regulations found in 29 CFR 1910.134 or European Standard
8. Exposure controls / personal protecti.20: EN 149. Use a NIOSH/MSHA or European Standard EN 149 approved respirator if
8. Exposure controls / personal protecti.21: exposure limits are exceeded or if irritation or other symptoms are experienced.
8. Exposure controls / personal protecti.22: Hygiene Measures Handle in accordance with good industrial hygiene and safety practice.
